author: _shemnon
content: Skipping the tests that won't wrap in an initcontainer is fine.  But I think we should throw all other invalid containers individually to each tx pool with a very high priority fee to see which clients attempt to include them.  We should also have some 64k+ initcontainers too (multiple 64k sub-containers)

author: _shemnon
content: This will be good as it flexes the txpool and blockbuilding, which we cannot do in reference tests.

author: ben_a_adams
content: <@403707149043105803> I've done some heavy refactoring of Nethermind, it passes all Eof tests; but I have a little worry I may have broke some tracing used in fuzzing (as don't think is test coverage there?). So let me know if so

author: _shemnon
content: Fuzzing is fine, but one deep fuzzing test broke instantly. I'll need to spend some time reducing it but I'll DM you the raw failed test.

author: _shemnon
content: Fuzzing is fixed.  A real interesting test case was discovered.
